definition: to reduce in amount, degree, or severity; The headache abated after taking medicine.
to hate or detest; She abhors cruelty to animals.
to refrain or hold back voluntarily; He abstained from smoking.
a gradual buildup or growth by addition; An accretion of dust covered the furniture.
sharp, biting, or caustic in tone; She made an acerbic retort.
to gain possession of; He acquired a taste for opera.
keen insight or judgment; She has excellent business acumen.
to stick fast or cleave; The stamp adhered to the envelope.
to caution or advise against; The teacher admonished the students not to be late.
friendly, good
relating to beauty or good taste; She appreciated modernist aesthetics in art.
to relieve or make more bearable; Medication helped alleviate her pain.
friendly and good
more than sufficient in size or scope; We had ample time to finish the test.
similar or comparable in certain respects; This process is analogous to how a cell works.
something that deviates from the norm; Finding the artifact was an archaeological anomaly.
a deep dislike or aversion; He had an antipathy for crowds.
chosen at random, without reason; It seemed an arbitrary decision, without rationale.

a strong feeling of dislike, distaste, or hostility; He had an aversion to spinach since childhood.
lacking originality, freshness, or novelty; The movie's banal plot was forgettable.
to make someone or something seem unimportant; The bullies belittled the shy student.
hostile, aggressive, or pugnacious; The belligerent gang was known for fighting.
characterized by or expressing goodwill; He made a benevolent donation to the animal shelter.

honesty, frankness, or sincere expression; I appreciated her candor and straightforward advice.

to punish or criticize severely; The boss castigated the employee for repeated mistakes.
blame or condemn; The senator was censured for unethical conduct.

expressing much in few words; a concise summary of the research findings.

guided by or in accordance with conscience or sense of right; governed by principle; a conscientious decision after much deliberation.

to consider thoughtfully; She contemplated all possible outcomes before deciding.
to give or supply along with others; We all contributed food to the potluck dinner.
scarcity or lack; There is a dearth of jobs in this struggling economy.
boldly resistant to authority or any opposing force; The defiant protestors refused to disperse.
fragile, frail, or vulnerable; requiring gentle handling; The delicate crystal shattered when dropped.

to ridicule, mock, or scornfully laugh at; The bullies derided the shy student's stutter.
depressing, bleak, lifeless; barren; The remote desert island was completely desolate.

causing gloom or depression; The dismal weather matched her sad mood.

relating to or believing in equality for all people; He advocated an egalitarian society.

prominent, distinguished, or noteworthy; The eminent scholar was awarded the Nobel Prize.
the ability to understand another's perspective, feelings, or difficulties; She showed genuine empathy for the grieving widow.
something or someone puzzling, mysterious, or difficult to understand; The coded message was an enigma they couldn't decipher.

to summon or call forth; Childhood photos evoked strong memories from long ago.
precise, accurate, or correct in every detail; Could you give me the exact amount needed?

silly, foolish, smugly ignorant; He made fatuous arguments that revealed little understanding of the issue.

frequently changing, erratic; His fickle behavior left her confused.
glaringly bad or offensive; a flagrant foul during the game; flagrant disregard for the law.

relevant and appropriate for the subject at hand; His rambling anecdote was not germane to the discussion.
serious; requiring consideration; The doctor had a grave expression when giving the prognosis.
sociable, seeking and enjoying the company of others; Humans are naturally gregarious and form bonds through social contact.
blatant, outrageous, or unambiguous; lacking refinement or dignity; His gross exaggerations undermined his credibility.
cunning, deceitful shrewdness or treachery; She betrayed her friend out of pure guile.
easily persuaded to believe something; naive, credulous; The scammer took advantage of gullible people.
arrogantly superior, disdainful, looking down on others; The haughty queen barely acknowledged the peasants.
to pause in uncertainty or have difficulty choosing; She hesitated before exiting the stage, nerves getting the best of her.

having or showing ill will, animosity, opposition; The hostile crowd shouted angrily at the politician.
exaggerated statements or claims not meant to be taken literally; Saying he was starving was hyperbole; he just wanted a snack.
one who attacks or undermines traditional conventions or institutions; The rebel was an iconoclast who challenged the status quo.
to worship or admire intensely and often excessively; Young girls often idolize celebrities and pop stars.
to supply or brighten with light; enlighten; His lecture helped illuminate and explain Plato's philosophy.
something that deceives or misleads intellectually; The magician created illusions that seemed to defy physics.

unchanging; unable to be changed or transformed; The laws of mathematics are immutable, fixed pillars of logic.
treating all sides equally; unbiased, objective; As a judge, she prided herself on being impartial.
to interfere with, slow the progress of, or obstruct; The fallen tree impeded traffic for hours.
about to happen, imminent, approaching; We prepared for the impending storm.
implied but not expressly stated; There was an implicit threat that loomed without being uttered.
acting on sudden desires or whims; prone to act on instinct rather than thought; Buying the expensive luxury car was an impulsive decision she later regretted.

unable or unwilling to believe something; She was incredulous that she won the lottery against such odds.

lack of interest, concern, or sympathy; His indifference towards her was obvious by his disengaged manner.
angrily offended due to perceived unfair treatment; I was indignant after being accused without cause.
impossible to question or doubt; unquestionable; The evidence was indisputable that he was guilty of the crime.
lacking power to move, lifeless, inactive; The car remained inert after the battery died.
impossible to avoid; certain to eventually happen; Death is the inevitable conclusion of life.
harmless, causing no damage or offense; The comments in her speech were innocuous enough not to provoke much reaction.
stealthily and harmfully treacherous or deceitful; Cancer can be an insidious disease, quietly spreading before detection.
firm adherence to moral principles; honesty, incorruptibility; Known for his integrity, they trusted he would do what was right.
possessing or displaying great concentration, zeal, or feeling; She spoke with intense passion that swayed the crowd.
occurring at irregular intervals; on and off; starting and stopping; The intermittent windshield wipers cleared the rain from the glass.
belonging naturally to someone or something; innate, inherent; Learning is an intrinsic reward of teaching.
immediate insight or understanding without conscious reasoning; He relied on intuition to make split
to overwhelm as if with a flood; My desk was inundated with paperwork.

turned inside out or upside down; reversed in position or order; The plane flew upside down in an inverted loop.
not applicable or related to the subject at hand; His rambling story was irrelevant to the topic being discussed.
showing lack of due respect or veneration; The student's irreverent remarks during chapel earned him a detention.

relating to or resulting from motion; kinetic or dynamic
possessing expertise or extensive information; My attorney is very knowledgeable about tax law.
using few words; terse, succinct; His laconic reply gave little information.

intentionally harmful, spiteful, or evil; spreading pernicious gossip for the sake of malice.

fame, celebrated reputation; cities of great renown that attract many tourists.

without previous instance; unparalleled; unprecedented success with her first album.

using more words than necessary; wordy; The professor's verbose lectures were packed with tangents and repetitiveness.
annoyance or irritation; a cause of irritation; Getting stuck in traffic is a daily vexation of my commute.
capable of working or being successfully implemented; a viable plan with a high chance of succeeding.
deliberately cruel or violent; The vicious criminal showed no remorse.
alertly watchful; carefully observant; vigilant against threats to their security.
robust, full of healthy energy; forceful, intense; She maintained a vigorous workout routine into old age.
loathsome; highly offensive or disgusting; They faced vile slurs from the unruly crowd.
morally excellent; righteous; She is a virtuous person, always trying to do good.
thick or sticky, having high resistance to flow; Molasses has a viscous texture.
absolutely essential; critically important; Funding for the project is vital to move forward.
producing powerful feelings or strong, clear images in the mind; She gave a vivid depiction of life growing up poor.
readily changing to a vapor; changeable, unstable; fickle; Gasoline is a volatile, flammable liquid.
to shift back and forth between opinions; equivocate; She kept waffling on where to eat, unable to make a choice.
pale, sickly, weak; lacking color or vitality; After weeks in bed sick, she was wan and drawn.
cautiously watchful; prudent; wary of strangers and slow to trust.
quirkily playful; fanciful; whimsical art full of strange creatures and imaginary worlds.
to shrivel or decay; plants withering without water; My enthusiasm withered under his hostile criticism.
using clever, sly, understated humor; She made wry jokes that hinted at her true feelings.
eager enthusiasm; fervor; She attacked the project with zeal despite obstacles.
passionately devoted; fervent; evangelical zeal motivated the group.
peak; highest point; climax; He reached the zenith of his acting career after the Oscar win.
gentle, mild breeze; The light zephyr barely rustled the leaves.
